doc1: It is a truth universally acknowledged, that a single man in possession of a good fortune, must be in want of a wife.
doc2: It is a widely accepted fact that a wealthy single man is inevitably in search of a wife.

doc1: However little known the feelings or views of such a man may be on his first entering a neighbourhood, this truth is so well fixed in the minds of the surrounding families, that he is considered as the rightful property of some one or other of their daughters.
doc2: No matter how little is known about a man's thoughts or intentions when he arrives in a new community, families around him firmly believe that he naturally belongs to one of their daughters.

doc1: "My dear Mr. Bennet," said his lady to him one day, "have you heard that Netherfield Park is let at last?"
doc2: "Mr. Bennet, my dear," his wife remarked one day, "did you hear that someone has finally rented Netherfield Park?"

doc1: Mr. Bennet replied that he had not.
doc2: Mr. Bennet responded that he had not heard.

doc1: "But it is," returned she; "for Mrs. Long has just been here, and she told me all about it."
doc2: "But it is true," she replied. "Mrs. Long was just here and shared all the details with me."

doc1: Mr. Bennet made no answer.
doc2: Mr. Bennet did not respond.

doc1: "Do not you want to know who has taken it?"
doc2: "Aren't you curious to find out who has rented it?"

doc1: cried his wife impatiently.
doc2: His wife exclaimed with impatience.

doc1: "_You_ want to tell me, and I have no objection to hearing it."
doc2: "You clearly want to tell me, and I don’t mind listening."

doc1: This was invitation enough.
doc2: That was more than enough encouragement.

doc1:
"Why, my dear, you must know, Mrs. Long says that Netherfield is taken by a young man of large fortune from the north of England; that he came down on Monday in a chaise and four to see the place, and was so much delighted with it that he agreed with Mr. Morris immediately; 
that he is to take possession before Michaelmas, and some of his servants are to be in the house by the end of next week."
doc2: Why, my dear, you ought to know that Mrs. Long reports Netherfield has been leased by a young man with great wealth from northern England; he visited on Monday in a chaise and four, loved the property so much that he finalized the deal with Mr. Morris right away; he plans to take possession before Michaelmas, with some of his servants moving in by next week’s end."

doc2: "But it’s quite possible he might fall in love with one of them, so you absolutely must call on him as soon as he arrives."

doc1: "I see no occasion for that.
doc2: "I don’t see any reason for that."

doc1: You and the girls may go, or you may send them by themselves, which perhaps will be still better, for as you are as handsome as any of them, Mr. Bingley might like you the best of the party."
doc2: "You and the girls can go, or perhaps it’s better if you send them alone, since you are just as beautiful as any of them, and Mr. Bingley might end up preferring you over the others."

doc1: "My dear, you flatter me.
doc2: "My dear, you are too kind."

doc1: I certainly _have_ had my share of beauty, but I do not pretend to be any thing extraordinary now.
doc2: "I’ve definitely enjoyed my share of beauty, but I don’t claim to be anything remarkable anymore."

doc1: When a woman has five grown up daughters, she ought to give over thinking of her own beauty."
doc2: "When a woman has five adult daughters, she should stop dwelling on her own looks."

doc1: "In such cases, a woman has not often much beauty to think of."
doc2: "In such situations, a woman usually doesn’t have much beauty left to consider."

doc1: "But, my dear, you must indeed go and see Mr. Bingley when he comes into the neighbourhood."
doc2: "But, my dear, you really must visit Mr. Bingley when he arrives in the area."

doc1: "It is more than I engage for, I assure you."

doc2: "I’m sure Mr. Bingley will be delighted to meet you; and I’ll send a note with you to let him know he has my full blessing to marry any of the girls he chooses, although I must put in a special recommendation for my dear Lizzy."

doc1: But you are always giving _her_ the preference."
doc2: "But you are constantly favoring her."

doc1: "They have none of them much to recommend them," replied he; "they are all silly and ignorant like other girls; but Lizzy has something more of quickness than her sisters."
doc2: "None of them have much to boast about," he replied, "they are all as foolish and uneducated as other girls; but Lizzy is a bit sharper than her sisters."

doc1: "Mr. Bennet, how can you abuse your own children in such a way?
doc2: "Mr. Bennet, how can you speak so harshly about your own children?"

doc2: "But I trust you’ll recover and live to witness many wealthy young men with four thousand a year moving into the area."

doc1: "It will be no use to us, if twenty such should come since you will not visit them."
doc2: "It won’t benefit us at all if twenty such men arrive, as you refuse to visit them."

doc1: "Depend upon it, my dear, that when there are twenty, I will visit them all."
doc2: "Rest assured, my dear, if there are twenty of them, I will visit every single one."

doc1: Mr. Bennet was so odd a mixture of quick parts, sarcastic humour, reserve, and caprice, that the experience of three and twenty years had been insufficient to make his wife understand his character.
doc2: Mr. Bennet was such a peculiar blend of sharp wit, sarcastic humor, reticence, and unpredictability that even after twenty-three years, his wife still couldn’t fully grasp his nature.

doc1: _Her_ mind was less difficult to develope.
doc2: Her personality was much easier to understand.

doc1: She was a woman of mean understanding, little information, and uncertain temper.
doc2: She was a woman of limited intelligence, scant knowledge, and a changeable disposition.

doc1: When she was discontented she fancied herself nervous.
doc2: When she felt unhappy, she imagined herself to be nervous.

doc1: The business of her life was to get her daughters married; its solace was visiting and news.
doc2: Her life’s mission was marrying off her daughters, and her comfort came from social visits and gossip.
